FARMERS' DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to us.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream, dugout)

If so far was this water from your house?

Here was it brought to the house? (gall, barrel, tank)

If not getting water supply, mention any chores which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

---

Poveshell had well for house use but in summer cattle and all other animals were taken to alongside to drink and in winter taken to lake and had to cut ice. Jan 1943 they got a dug out. After homestead we had a well at Poveshell which we tried all our stock and sometimes the neighbors watered 60 head of cattle and hauled in pasture.

In winter tanks to lake and had to cut ice. In 1948 they got a dug out, after I married we had a well as yet. This which we tried all new stock and had to haul in from neighbor's well 60 Road 7 cattle and horses.

14. FUEL

Position any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping. Giving reason where possible.

In the last five years about 1/3 or using oil burned in winter but most of them still used wood in summer. A few have the hotbeds for straw for summer. Usually burn wood in fall and keep a coal oil stove for summer.

17. Give a typical dinner menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest days in your family history. Give the names and ages of the members, etc., if known.

In July 1906 for supper, my mother had roast wild duck with dressing & gravy. Homemade new green peas, radishes & white cabbage. It was bread & butter. Sautéed onions with cream sauce. Tasted good but I could not drink the tea. The tea was always had quarter in the water.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? Give the menu, list those present and give total approximate cost at that time.

Wm. Knowles (father) age 42, Alice Knowles (mother) age 34, Barbara age 14, Mildred 15, Johnnie 13, Eddie 9, Lee 7, Alfred 5 and Ellen 3.

Mary V. Lee age 15, Mrs. Andrew Knowles age 44 and daughter Mary V. Lee age 15. Mrs. Andrew Knowles age 44 and daughter Mary V. Lee age 15.

Birds, stuffing, cranberry sauce, apple pie, yams, rolls.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No we always had milk, bread and meat if not our own land and seldom was without vegetables.
17. Give a typical dinner menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for two earliest children who were born in 1906. Give the date of each meal. Tell the names of all family members present at each meal.

In June 1906 for supper, my mother had roast wild duck with dressing & gravy. Homemade bread & butter. Salad thrown with cream & sugar.

Tasted good only I could not drink the tea. Heart tea. This almost had quail tea in it. (Note)

That year glad you serve your fires Christmas dinner in eastern Kansas approximately at that time.

18. Write names (father age 42, Alice known mother age 34, Barbara age 14, Michael 15, Johnnie 13, Eddie 9, Lee 7, Alfred 5 and Elsie 3).

Mary V. Vace age 15 + 1/2. A dear mother & 41 years old. Mary & Henry. Barbara & Elsie. We had roast chicken & dressing & gravy. Bread & butter & honey. Cranberry sauce, apple pie. Yum yum.

In early days all meals prepared were boiled, fried or roasted in tin or ironware. Now they are usually prepared in Oyex, Pressure cookers or waterless cookers. In early days we had to prepare all meals now there are so much in cans and all purpose foods that it is much easier but I still do not believe healthier.

When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still like to prepare my own but ever since 1922 have bought many canned tomatoes, noodles, Kraft dinners since 1940 and many other articles canned fish, meat etc.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

No. - Continued - When we loaded our car at Manuel No. 11, in April, 1906. My father put in two nice black cows so we could raise our own pork. They took them at the time as they could not cross to the Canadian side. So we had to wait until the year 1907 when our neighbor brought some from Quebec. Father bought two and after 6 months we had our own pork as there always was frozen wheat to feed them and could not sell it.
